prior_works.title: Chaos in neuronal networks with balanced excitatory and inhibitory activity
prior_works.role: Foundational theory of E–I balanced, irregular dynamics in random sparse networks
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s strong, fast random synapse set explicitly leverages the balanced-chaos mechanism of van Vreeswijk & Sompolinsky to generate the fast, irregular E–I background into which the attractor computation is embedded.

prior_works.title: Dynamics of sparsely connected networks of excitatory and inhibitory spiking neurons
prior_works.role: Canonical analysis of asynchronous irregular states and the impact of synaptic time constants
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Brunel’s characterization of asynchronous irregular firing and synaptic kinetics underpins the paper’s use of fast synapses for irregular activity and clarifies how synaptic timescales shape the fast background dynamics.

prior_works.title: Theory of orientation tuning in visual cortex
prior_works.authors: Ronen Ben-Yishai, R. Lev Bar-Or, Haim Sompolinsky
prior_works.role: Seminal continuous attractor (ring) model establishing structured recurrent interactions for bump states
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The study’s weak, slow synapse set implements a continuous attractor akin to the Ben-Yishai ring, providing the structured manifold that supports stable bump-like activity within the balanced network.

prior_works.title: Representation of spatial orientation by the intrinsic dynamics of the head-direction cell ensemble: a theory
prior_works.role: Foundational CANN for head-direction with continuous manifolds and bump dynamics
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Zhang’s CANN framework motivates the paper’s choice of continuous attractor computation and informs how weak structured connectivity can encode a continuous variable within a larger circuit.

prior_works.title: Effects of neuromodulation in a cortical network model of object working memory
prior_works.role: Demonstrated coexistence of irregular spiking with persistent activity via fast AMPA/GABA and slow NMDA
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work’s separation of fast and slow synaptic components directly inspires the paper’s two-synapse-set design, generalizing it to a setting where the slow component is weak and structured to realize a CANN within a balanced background.

prior_works.title: Slow dynamics and high variability in balanced cortical networks with clustered excitatory connectivity
prior_works.role: Showed that structured connectivity embedded in balanced networks yields metastable attractor-like states and variability
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The current paper extends this embedding idea from clustered discrete attractors to continuous attractors, showing that weak structure can coexist with balanced irregular dynamics when made slow.

prior_works.title: Linking connectivity, dynamics and computation in low-rank recurrent neural networks
prior_works.role: Theory of adding weak low-rank structure to random connectivity to carve computational subspaces and slow modes
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s weak, slow structured synapses effectively act as a low-rank perturbation that creates an outlier manifold (the CANN) within random balanced dynamics, aligning with the low-rank-plus-random framework.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution—demonstrating that continuous attractor computation can be embedded within fast, irregular E–I balanced dynamics by separating synapses into strong/fast and weak/slow sets—sits at the intersection of three lines of work. First, balanced network theory (van Vreeswijk & Sompolinsky; Brunel) established that sparse random E–I connectivity with sufficiently strong interactions produces asynchronous, irregular activity governed by fast synaptic kinetics. This provides the fast, high-variance background dynamics the present study explicitly harnesses with its strong, fast synapses.
Second, continuous attractor neural networks (Ben-Yishai et al.; Zhang) showed that stable bump manifolds arise from structured recurrent interactions, offering a canonical mechanism for representing continuous variables. The current paper instantiates this with a weak structured component that is intentionally slow, ensuring that attractor dynamics evolve on timescales distinct from the fast balanced fluctuations.
Third, prior demonstrations that structured connectivity can coexist with balanced dynamics (Litwin-Kumar & Doiron) and that weak low-rank structure embedded in random networks yields computationally meaningful slow modes (Mastrogiuseppe & Ostojic) directly motivate the architectural decomposition used here. Complementing these, Brunel & Wang’s separation of fast AMPA/GABA and slow NMDA currents foreshadows the two-timescale synaptic design, now generalized to a random balanced substrate with a weak, slow CANN. Together, these works converge on the insight that a slow, low-amplitude structured component can carve an attractor manifold within a fast, strongly balanced random network, enabling coexistence and mutual compatibility of E–I irregularity and continuous attractor computation.
